title: England rugby boss Eddie Jones reveals Jose Mourinho's surprise role in their success after Cardiff thriller
text:
Sport England rugby boss Eddie Jones reveals Jose Mourinho's surprise role in their success after Cardiff thriller It's now 16 wins in a row for a team whose revamped training follows principles backed by the Manchester United manager Share England are a much fitter squad than the one Jones took over late in 2015 (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
An old pal of Jose Mourinho helped put England on world-record course, Eddie Jones has revealed. 
Victory away to Wales on Saturday gave the Red Rose a 16th straight win and moved them to within two home Six Nations matches, against Italy and Scotland, of New Zealand’s record. 
Win those, and history will await in the tournament finale away to Ireland. 
It was the second time in eight days that Jones’ team had thrillingly come from behind to triumph at the death, having fought back from 16-12 down with 10 minutes remaining to beat France. 
And after the dust settled on a pulsating contest in Cardiff, the Australian admitted to finding the secret ingredient to England’s success on a secret mission to the Middle East. 
It was in Qatar that he met exercise physiologist Alberto Mendez-Villanueva and learned the training method, favoured by football bosses Mourinho and Andre Villas-Boas, which has transformed England late in games. Elliot Daly sprinted in at the corner late on to win the match... (Photo: Rex Features) ...and make it 16 straight English victories — 15 of them under boss Jones (Photo: Getty) 
“It’s a methodology which I’ve borrowed from soccer called tactical periodisation,” Jones explained. “It has improved our fitness enormously. 
“Every day we train a specific parameter of the game. 
"We have one day where we have a physical session and do more contacts than we would do in a game. Then we have a fast day where we try to train for at least 60 per cent of the session above game-speed. 
"We don’t do any extra fitness. It’s all done within those training sessions.” 
A week after Ben Te’o struck eight minutes from time to beat France, Elliot Daly broke Welsh hearts with a 76th-minute winner in Cardiff. 
Jones joked afterwards that England had used up all their get-out-of-jail-free cards, but the science behind their training suggests it is less down to luck than preparation. 
As Mourinho put it: “For me, training means to train in specificity. That is, to create exercises that allow me to exacerbate my principles of play.” England have taken a page out of Mourinho's book to improve late in games (Photo: Man Utd via Getty) 
When Jones took over the England job, he quickly concluded fitness levels were not high enough to beat the best. 
He was shocked by England’s ‘bounce time’ – the period between a player hitting the turf and getting back into the game. 
“I think some of the blokes had a cup of tea and a scone with jam and cream before they got off the ground,” he recalled. “It was terrible. In terms of getting off the ground we are still seven per cent below New Zealand – so we are still not where we need to be. 
“We are not happy being the best team in Europe, we want to be the best in the world.” 
For much of Saturday’s game, they did not even look the best team in Cardiff. 
They started well and led through a fine team try, finished by Ben Youngs on the 26th phase. England scored the game's first try when scrum-half Youngs went over from close-in... (Photo: Rex Features) ...but Wales were then on top for much of the match until Daly's clincher (Photo: Reuters) 
But Wales then took charge — and would have won but for two factors. 
Firstly, Jones is a master at deploying his bench, even if it meant hauling off captain Dylan Hartley with the second half just six minutes old. 
Their bench boys made a serious impact. Wales’ did not. 
But above all England now believe so strongly in their levels of fitness that they do not recognise a lost cause. 
“We know we can wear teams down,” said Jones. “We were always in a position to win.” Wing Williams went over for the hosts after a well-worked backline move (Photo: AFP/Getty) Read More Skipper Hartley insists he's still a key man despite being subbed seven minutes into second half 
The energy and determination not to lose, he added, had been forged in the crucible of humiliation. 
“Some of them were here (in Cardiff) in 2013 when they got their pants pulled down,” he said. “A lot were involved in the World Cup where they got beaten in the pools.” 
Those nightmares are distant memories.
